Jack The Ripeur is a digital transformation project for waste management in the city of Lyon, developed as part of the digital transformation module during my studies at Epitech. The goal was to support a large-scale change through a communication strategy, training, performance monitoring, and sustainability. The whole project was symbolized by the creation of a visual identity and a mascot: Bin-E.

Zoidberg 2.0 is a computer-aided diagnosis project aiming to detect pneumonia from chest X-rays using machine learning techniques. It was developed as part of a semester-long project at Epitech.

objectif.heading: üéØ Goal
content: Design a full pipeline to:

• Prepare and analyze 4K chest X-ray images
  • Train machine learning models to detect pneumonia
  • Compare performance using different approaches (cross-validation, train-test split...)
  • Present results clearly and reproducibly

approche.heading: üß† Methodological Approach
content:
• Custom class for loading, visualizing, and preprocessing data
  • Image normalization and resizing (224√ó224)
  • Label distribution visualization (pneumonia vs. normal)
  • Using K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) as the baseline algorithm
  • Evaluation with accuracy_score and confusion_matrix
  • Exploration of advanced metrics such as ROC-AUC (planned)

dataset.heading: üìÅ Dataset
content: The data is split into three sets: train, validation, and test, accessible via an internal URL. Each image is a chest X-ray manually annotated by healthcare professionals.

technos.heading: üîß Technologies used
content:
• Python (main language)
  • Pandas / NumPy for data manipulation
  • scikit-learn for ML algorithms and metrics
  • Matplotlib / Seaborn for visualization
  • PIL for image handling

fonctionnalites.heading: üöÄ Key Features
content:
• Interactive image exploration and labeling
  • Automated preprocessing pipeline
  • Cross-validation support for model selection
  • Graphical display of prediction errors
  • Comparison of validation methods (simple split vs. k-fold)

defis.heading: ‚ö†Ô∏è Technical Challenges
content:
• Managing large 4K image files
  • Maintaining bias/variance trade-off
  • Interpreting results on sensitive medical data
  • Ensuring experiment reproducibility (saving/loading models)

This project was carried out during my first work-study program in the third year of my Electrical and Industrial IT bachelor's degree (BUT GEII). The goal: to automate a monthly activity report of over 60 pages, which was previously manually generated using Excel and Power BI. The automation aimed to save time, improve reliability, and enhance readability for the teams.

objectifs.heading: üéØ Goals
content: Replace the manual production of Word and PDF reports with a fully automated process capable of:

• Reducing manual monthly workload from 5‚Äì7 hours to just 10‚Äì20 minutes
  • Extracting and processing data from Excel files and an Access database
  • Dynamically generating tables and charts based on the monthly volume
  • Automatically creating a paginated PDF report with multipage table handling
  • Eliminating human error in calculations and formatting
  • Provide a maintainable and scalable solution, usable by non-technical people.

technos.heading: üîß Technologies used
content:
• Python for data processing and dynamic page generation
  • Dash (Flask-based) for the web interface
  • Plotly for interactive charts
  • Openxyl to extract data from Excel files
  • pandas for data cleaning, filtering, and grouping
  • Excel + Power Query for database structuring

fonctionnalites.heading: üìÑ Key Features
content:
• Data collection from multiple Excel files (indicators, appendices, regulatory analyses...)
  • Automatic generation of multi-index tables and charts (Dash DataTable)
  • Dynamic pagination based on row count (auto page breaks)
  • Table of contents with dynamic links and auto-managed page numbers
  • PDF export ready for printing and client delivery

defis.heading: üí° Challenges
content:
• Creating dynamic pivot tables ‚Äì not natively supported by Dash, so custom formatting was needed to match client expectations
  • Positioning footers precisely on each page
  • Building dynamic tables with pagination based on content
  • Handling multiple and inconsistent data sources
  • Optimizing Python code to ensure fast response times
  • Continuous improvement based on weekly user feedback

resultats.heading: üöÄ Results
content: The automated MAR (Monthly Activity Report) significantly reduced generation time: from 5‚Äì7 hours manually to an average of 15 minutes. It improved data reliability and reduced workload on a previously time-consuming task. The interface is accessible via a standard browser (internal server deployment in progress). The solution is fully documented (installation guide, user manual, developer guide) and can be adapted for other contracts.
